data.title: The first Bahmani-Vijaynagra war (1362-1366)

data.text:
By giving a read to the history of Bahmanis, it appears to me that militarily they had upper hand over Vijaynagar, not only they repulsed every invasion from the latter but also made counter-invasion on most of the occasion, penetrating deep into vijaynagar empire and levying tribute from them. But they had no solution for guerrilla style of warfare of Vijaynagaris. Vijaynagris , despite of having larger military force (many times larger), tried to avoid confronting Bahmanis in open battle in their own homeland and harassed the smaller forces of invaders with guerrella tactics. Bahmanis would feel the danger of getting completely overwhelmed and would retreat back to their own empire. Then Vijayanagar would offer peace terms and would agree to pay tributes for time being .

The lacs of infantry of vijaynagar, it seems lacked quality , were perhaps not warriors but recruits from common peasants. They were numerous but not warriors of Rajput caliber.

What ever i have shared in the opening, he has provided extensive notes and references for it at the end of the chapter which i have skipped along with the the side details in the chapter itself.

Your random use of the words like "Hindu nationalists" won't give any more legitimacy to your claim. According to Ferishta himself concluding treaty at the end of the war recognized Krishna river as boundary between two polities. If Bahamanis were indeed as successful in thrashing Vijayanagar as Ferishta wants us to believe then they would have gained control of the territory south to Krishna. But rather the territory ended up being part of Vijayanagar (with some territory under mutual control of both). So unless or until we assume that Ferishta also wants us to believe that Bahmanis were stupid and ..... that even after thrashing Vijayanagar completely couldn't manage make any substantial gains, there is no reason to take whatever he says on face value. The only thing in which Bahmanis were expert at was the whole sale massacre of population.

Bahmanis could have conquered Vijaynagar, but they knew that they wont be able to keep the occupation and rule vast kingdom of Vijaynagar with entirely Hindu population. Keeping it as tributary was more beneficial. So it was their policy to not outstretch themselves too thin by expanding southwards. They also didnt expand Northwards. When Bahmani sultanate split into five pieces, its Bijapur and golconda pieces had no choice but to increase its territoty southwards, they made their mind and they did it successfully, annihilating the Vijaynagar empire in the process. So if the two smaller split away states from bahmani could absorb Vijaynagar, why you think their parent Bahmani was not capable of it?. Due to disslution of Afghan empires and chiefdoms at the hands of Mughals, large number of soldiers were available to Deccan sultanates to deal with vijaynagar efficiently and maintain the occupation in conquered territories.

You need to read better sources than Ferishta. Its easy to prove that Vijayanagara held the upper hand over the Bahamani Sultanate, since we have independent record of the Bahamani kings ceding land to end hostilities. Vijayanagara kings didn't cede land, they never recognized the Bahamani encroachment.

Also, Vijayanagara had two adversaries- Bahamani and the Gajapatis, with the Gajapatis being the superior one. Bahamanis had only one adversary, Vijayanagara.
